citation.article-title: Description of two new species of Halomonas: Halomonas israelensis sp.nov. and Halomonas canadensis sp.nov.

p.s: Description of Halomonas catadensis sp. nov.
Halomonas catadensis (cana.den.sis; pertaining to Canada)

The following description is based on the observations of Vreeland (1984) as amended by the data in this paper. Halomonas catadensis appears as straight or curved Gram-negative rods with rounded ends.
They divide by transverse fission, and occur singly, in pairs, or short chains.
Pleomorphic cells are not present.
Both culture age and NaCl concentration affect chain length.
Pleomorphic cells are not present.
Spores are not formed.
They are motile by a single polar flagellum.
Colonies formed on complex CAS medium with 8% NaCl 2-6 mm in diameter after 7 days at 30°C.
Colonies produce a nondiffusible white pigment.
The colonies are translucent and convex with a smooth glistening surface.
They grow from pH 5.0 to 9.0 in CAS medium with 8.0% NaCl.
The optimal temperature is 30°C and they are aerobic and halotolerant. Halomonas canadensis grows well from 3.0 to 25% NaCl and from 15 to 30°C.
It grows poorly below 1.0% NaCl and cannot grow without some NaCl added to its medium.
It grows in medium with 8 to 32% NaCl at 45°C and cannot grow below 5°C.
Halomonas canadensis requires Na+ ions for growth and KCl Will not substitute for NaCl.
It is catalase positive and cytochrome oxidase negative, but Kovac's oxidase test may give a positive reaction.
It reduces NO3 to NO2 and produces indole.
Lysine and ornithine decarboxylases are present.
This species is phenylalanin deaminase negative and grows throughout a thioglycollate tube supplemented with 8.0% NaCl.
The present strain is urease negative although the original isolate may have been urease postive (Vreeland 1984).
Cultures lyse in distilled water.
H2S and acetylmethyl carbinol are not produced.
The addition of Ca+2 to its medium is not required.
Gelatin, casein, starch and agar are not utilized.

It is insensitive to valinomycin, monensin, aphidicolin, penicillin G, ampicillin, streptomycin, vibriostat 0.129, and novoblocin (see Vreeland 1984),and is sensitive to chloramphenicol and oxytetracycline (see Vreeland 1984).
The following compounds have been found to serve as sole sources of carbon and energy in chemically defined media: acetate, citrate, DL-malate, succinate, lactate, glucose, xylose.
L-arabinose, D-fructose, D-mannitol, mesoinositol, ethanol, mannose, aesculin, glycerol, and gluconic acid.
In the present study, this bacterium utilized cellobiose, lactose, and sucrose, but these three sources were not used according to a previous description (Vreeland 1984).

This species cannot utilize butyrate, isobutyrate, propionate, tartarate, benzoate, maltose, melibiose, L-sorbose, D-ribose, D-sorbitol, n-propanol, n-butanol, ethylene glycol, n-hexadecane, pyridine-1-oxide, fonnaldehyde, formamide, N,N-dimethylacetamide, and ethylenediamine.
The G+C content of this species is 57 ± 1 mol% (buoyant density) and 54-55 mol% (thermal denaturation).
The DNA shows 55% homology to H. dongala ATCC 33173T, 34% homology to H. halodurans ATCC 29686T, and 20% homology to H. israelensis ATCC 43985T when determined by the dot blot method.
This species has been isolated as a contaminant on Sehgal and Gibbons medium containing 25% NaCl (Mathesoo et al. 1976).
The type strain of this species is NRCC 41227T (=ATCC 43984).
